im not really an expert on the phenomenon - but i do have a theory (tell me if im wrong) - there is a certain connection with P, V and T in gases and liquids (van der waals). lets think of a bang on the table as an infinitesimal event in time. the volume of the bottle stays nearly constant (that bang may have changed it microscopically for a very short period). the temperature should stay pretty much constant (lets ignore the fact that heat transfers from your hand to the bottle). so, we should get that overall pressure stays the same. BUT, the bang itself isn't there to ignore, it must cause some change in pressure at a part of the bottle - meaning that there has to be a difference in pressure through the bottle. if the pressure is high enough in some part of the bottle, water will start turning into ice and expand - causing more pressure on the water that hasn't turned into ice yet. this recursive effect should turn all the water into ice, and then melt back into water because of the rise in temperature.

The reason it took multiple attempts to pull this off with so-called "pure water" is because Fiji isn't "pure water." It's ground water, so by its very nature, it should have salts (aka minerals) dissolved in it. This is pretty common for bottled water as drinking water usually isn't "pure" water. If you want this to work better, try distilled water, as it actually is just water. It's not very good for drinking, and you won't find it in small bottles for that very reason, but because it has very few to no dissolved salts, it should have no available nucleation points. That's also why you shouldn't microwave distilled water. If you pull it out and it isn't visibly boiling, breaking the surface tension can cause "superheating" (to make up a word), and the water will actually explode out of the container as steam is instantly released.

This is an interesting principle, and it's worthy of note that it also applies to other substances. Interestingly enough, these substances don't need to freeze at 0 degrees Celsius - the cooling just has to progress below the solidification temperature natural for that substance. As the crystals form, the temperature of the liquid will go back up to the temperature of solidification. This principle is used in hand-warmers - the "click" you hear is a little piece of metal that, when bent, provides a seed on its surface for the crystals to begin forming. As they form, the temperature of the resulting solid rises - and this provides the heat that warms your hands. As to where the heat comes from, I can't recall, so you'll have to look it up. ^^

I used to be able to do this consistently with Dasani water. That was when Dasani was new to the mass market. Since then the bottle and probably the water itself has changed and now it's much more difficult to recreate. It seemed to me at the time that a few factors were responsible. The bottle was thick (rigid plastic) and well sealed, which kept the water under pressure and ice crystals from forming. Water is naturally denser at 4 C than when frozen, but keeping the bottle under pressure extends this dense state to temperatures below freezing. A freezing point a few degrees below 0 is then required to exert enough pressure on the casing to form ice crystals. To test this, simply open or gently puncture the super-cooled pressured bottle and it will turn to an ice crystal. There are probably other methods, such as using monopolar ions or electrical currents, but I would venture to guess that in the common super-cooled water bottle trick, pressure plays a significant part.

Nucleation sites are also important in boiling. If the water doesn't have a place to break the surface tension, like a scratch in metal, it is difficult for bubbles to form (called nucleate boiling). If there are too few nucleation sites, steam blankets the surface insulating it and driving up the temperature further to maintain that heat transfer. It IS possible to supercool impure water.  I've done it with carbonated soda, and I suspect Gatorade is possible, too.  Carbonated soda is risky to do this with, as it can explode the container if you "miss" the supercooling window and regular ice forms.  Pure water is much easier to do this with, and other beverages are more difficult - but not impossible.

It's perfectly fine - and a good idea on a hot day.  It's not pure solid ice, and it's not a process which continues for very long - it's more of a dense slush. Water freezes in a crystalline formation. You can't have semi solid water because semi crystals can't physically exist. A similar type of thing is Ionic compounds. They too can't form semi crystalline states. Ounce a crystal starts forming any movement in the liquid that makes the crystal bigger starts locking into place. Water has the least density at the temperature of 4 degrees Celsius. Above that temperature more energy will cause the molecules move faster and thus expands the volume. Below 4 degrees molecules move less and hydrogen bonds can form, which take up more space, thus expanding it. It triggers for a completely different reason.  Beer has ethyl alcohol in it at about 6-8% volume, which under normal circumstances will hydrogen bond with water and destroy any symmetry of the system.  When you bang a beer bottle, you are breaking loose the chemical bond between C3H6(OH) and the water, allowing the water to immediately freeze. The rapid ice freezing locks the beer particles in place and cools the alcohol, which forms its own ice in the core of the mass.

What he didn't explain (or possibly didn't know) is that water has to actually reach about 5 degrees below the freezing point to turn to ice. The phase transition releases heat that brings the temperature back up to 0 Celsius, but if you just cool water to -2 to -3 degrees, it remains a liquid (regardless of whether you bang on it). The trick is to get it to exactly the critical point. What you need is a point-and-shoot infrared thermometer to get it right easily.

Correct, but that does not explain why (sometimes) the hotter bottle freezes earlier, just that due to the higher gradient (at first) it cools down faster. Ultimately the hotter one reaches the temperature of the cooler one, and from then on, it presumably takes the same amount of time to cool till freezing.

Take two bottles with the same (amount) of water, but with one at a higher temperature and the other at room temperature, put them in the freezer, and predict which of them (room temperature or higher temperature) will freeze first. Then try it out yourself. The test will surprise you!

Two things: 1: There is air space in the bottle for expansion (you can see the bubble of air in his bottle). 2: The ice that forms is not as "solid" as ice you find if the water had been frozen for a while.
